availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Laban Thomas Moore (Representative, colonel, and Lawrence Co attorney)

body.p: Kentucky attorney, politician, and soldier. Cabell County, Virginia, native. Son of Frederick William Moore. Married to Sarah A. Everett Moore on January 15, 1850. Father of Felicia E. Moore, Mary F. Moore, S. G. Moore, Minnie H. Moore, and Druzilla Moore. Attended Marshall Academy. Graduate of Marietta College. Studied law at Transylvania University. Admitted to the bar in 1849. Member of the Whig Party and Democratic Party. Attorney in Lawrence County in 1850. Served the Ninth Congressional District of Kentucky as an Opposition Party member of the United States House of Representatives from 1859 to 1861. Attorney in Lawrence County, Kentucky in 1860. Served in the 14th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry (U.S.A.) as a colonel from November 1861 to January 1862.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Lawrence County, p. 75B.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Lawrence County, Louisa, p. 186.

Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Lawrence County, p. 333B.
E. Polk Johnson, A History of Kentucky and Kentuckians: The Leaders and
Representative Men in Commerce, Industry, and Modern Activities, Vol. 3 (Chicago, IL: Lewis Publishing Company, 1912), p. 1562-1564.

Mt. Sterling Advocate (Mount Sterling, Ky.), November 15, 1892.
Find A Grave, “Laban Theodore Moore (January 13, 1829-November 9, 1892),” http://www.findagrave.com/memorial/7773434 (accessed December 20, 2016).
